abstract.text: Values that define the widget’s size and shape.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Widgets can support one or more sizes, giving users the flexibility to
configure their widgets however they like. Each widget size provides a
different amount of space for detail, so consider which sizes work best for
the type of information the widget displays. For more information about
designing widgets, see
or
The sizes of widgets may vary across devices. Your widget content
should be flexible and avoid using fixed values.
You specify the sizes your widget supports using the
property modifier when defining your widget’s configuration.

code: .description("Shows an overview of your game status")

inlineContent.text: When WidgetKit needs to load a widget’s timeline, it calls the
class’s
method. The system
passes a
instance to the method’s
parameter. Use the context’s
property to determine the
widget’s size and shape. For example, the
family represents a small, square
widget on the Home Screen or Today View in iOS or iPadOS, while, in watchOS
the
family appears as
a widget-based complication in the corner of a watch face.
Use the
value to return the appropriate content
given the widget’s size. For example,
a
widget may focus on showing only
the most critical data, such as a single image or a simple gauge, while
a
widget can contain additional
details, more-complex graphs, and even small blocks of text.

abstract.text: Extend the reach of your app by creating widgets, watch complications, Live Activities, and controls.
Leverage WidgetKit’s API to create watchOS complications using SwiftUI.
Display your app’s content in a convenient, informative widget on various devices.
Support accessory widgets that appear on the Lock Screen and as complications on Apple Watch.

doc://com.apple.WidgetKit/documentation/.title: Creating accessory widgets and watch complications

abstract.text: An object describing the content of a widget that has no user-configurable
options.
Offer widgets in additional contexts by adding support for various widget sizes.
A type that advises WidgetKit when to update a widget’s display.
Provides an array of timeline entries for the current time and,
optionally, any future times to update a widget.
An object that contains details about how a widget is rendered, including
its size and whether it appears in the widget gallery.
The user-configured family of the widget: small, medium, or large.
Constants that indicate the rendering mode for an
in when displayed in a widget
in
mode.
Values that define the widget’s size and shape.
A circular widget.
A widget-based complication in the corner of a watch face in watchOS.
A flat widget that contains a single row of text and an optional image.
A rectangular widget.
An extra-large widget.
A large widget.
A medium-sized widget.
A small widget.
Constants that indicate the rendering mode for a widget.
The system divides the widget’s view hierarchy into an accent group and
a default group, applying a different color to each group.
Offer Live Activities, controls, animate data updates, and add interactivity to widgets.

doc://com.apple.WidgetKit/documentation/.title: Emoji Rangers: Supporting Live Activities, interactivity, and animations

abstract.text: Create an app with persistent data, interactive widgets, and an all new in-app purchase experience.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Backyard Birds: Building an app with SwiftData and widgets

abstract.text: The configuration and content of a widget to display on the Home screen or in Notification Center.
A container used to expose multiple widgets from a single widget extension.
Sets the sizes that a widget supports.
Create a shared codebase to build a multiplatform app that offers widgets and an App Clip.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Fruta: Building a Feature-Rich App with SwiftUI

abstract.text: Create widgets to show your app’s content on the Home screen, with custom intents for user-customizable settings.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Building Widgets Using WidgetKit and SwiftUI

abstract.text: A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type that can be converted to and from an associated raw value.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
